image:image.image:title: Art Portfolio - White Flag under Trump
image:image.image:caption: Getting political here. Shortly before his inauguration, I wrote a series of posts about art and Trump for Symbiartic on Scientific American, and included this burning flag of surrender illustration. Created on iPad in ArtRage and Halftone. Links: Don't Close the Studio Door Stop Saying Art Will Flourish Under Trump Art Vs Trump Roundup Museums Will Rescue Us

image:image.image:title: Art Portfolio - Life As a Trilobite
image:image.image:caption: The original painting of what become my Trilobite Boy character. Oil on canvas. Blog post Prints

image:image.image:title: Art Portfolio - Trilobite Boy Rocks Out
image:image.image:caption: Commissioned painting. Oil on wood panel. Blog post Prints

image:image.image:title: Art Portfolio - Dimetrodon Sphinx
image:image.image:caption: A character from the same world as Trilobite Boy. Pencil, painted on iPhone 4 using the Sketch Club app.

image:image.image:title: Art Portfolio - Trilobite Boy - Late Sk8
image:image.image:caption: Trilobite Boy on his way to the Royal Ontario Museum. I tried a small series of quick sketches of the character as an exercise for a couple of weeks. ArtRage Studio Pro. Blog Post Tees Available : : iPhone Cases Available

image:image.image:title: Art Portfolio - Trilobite Boy - Waking
image:image.image:caption: Trilobite Boy waking up from an enrolled position. He's more trilobite than boy when he sleeps. Part of a small series of quick sketches of the character that I did as an exercise for a couple of weeks. ArtRage Studio Pro. Blog Post

image:image.image:title: Art Portfolio - Trilobite Boy - Fans
image:image.image:caption: Part of a small series of quick sketches of the character that I did as an exercise for a couple of weeks. ArtRage Studio Pro. Blog Post Tees available - after a number of requests, I made the t-shirt design available that the girl on the left is wearing. Been pretty popular, too!

image:image.image:title: Art Portfolio - Trilobite Boy - Butter Tarts
image:image.image:caption: The last in the series of quick sketches with this character. His favourite breakfast is the Canadian dessert, butter tarts. Painted in ArtRage Pro. Blog post

image:image.image:title: Art Portfolio - Prehistoric Fish
image:image.image:caption: A sketch, later painted in ArtRage for iPad. Blog post Time-lapse video

image:image.image:title: Art Portfolio - Trilobite Eggs
image:image.image:caption: An old sketch painted in ArtRage for iPad using a Wacom Intuos Creative Stylus II. Interestingly, shortly after I posted this online, a new discovery about trilobite eggs was published. Blog post

image:image.image:title: Art Portfolio - Incredible Hulk Anatomy (fan art)
image:image.image:caption: Hulk © Marvel Comics. Done without permission but reshared by Agent M via Twitter and Tumblr. This illustration was also chosen as the Image of the Week on Scientific American, and seen on io9, Neatorama, and many more sites. Blog post, (including captions)

image:image.image:title: Art Portfolio - Trapping Man-Thing (fan art)
image:image.image:caption: Man-Thing © Marvel Comics. Fan art. Painted in ArtRage, with the pencil sketch side by side. Love this character. Blog post

image:image.image:title: Art Portfolio
Tattoo Design - Trilobite Astrology
image:image.image:caption: Trilobite Astrology - since the stars appeared in different configurations 500 million years ago than they do now, this was my absurd commentary on the idea of astrology. Astrology is nonsense - but I did have some fun with a first wave of trilobite designs based on astrological attributes. Each one has the appropriate ancient symbol incorporated into the design.

image:image.image:title: Tattoo Design
Tattoo Design
image:image.image:caption: Allosaurus. The first of 3 for author Riley Black @Laelaps. This one has two hidden landmarks with personal connotations for Riley hidden away in it.

image:image.image:title: Tattoo Design
image:image.image:caption: Ceratosaurus for author Riley Black. possibly my favourite of the 3 commissions.

image:image.image:title: Tattoo Design
Tattoo Design
Tattoo Design
Tattoo Design - Torvosaurus Ink
image:image.image:caption: Torvosaurus Ink - The third Morrison Formation predator tattoo commissioned by author Riley Black, and inked by Austin Huffman at Heart of Gold in Utah. I love doing these, and this one came looking fantastic.

image:image.image:title: Tattoo Design - Tylosaurus Ink
image:image.image:caption: Tylosaurus Ink - A variant version of a private commission, intended for the left shoulder (tail) and chest (skull). I textured the dark and light patches across the skeleton to mimic the pattern of shadows from waves; it also gives it a ferocious tiger-like pattern. Please do not reproduce this one without permission from me.

image:image.image:title: Tattoo Design
Tattoo Design - Mitochondrial Eve
image:image.image:caption: This student painting of mine about the Mitochondrial Eve theory of biology was painted using traditional oil paint materials on canvas sized with rabbit-skin glue over an aged wooden board. @torsopromise surprised me one day in 2019 asking if I was okay with them getting a tattoo of the image. I was delighted, and it looks fantastic. Ink work by @WillSheldon.

image:image.image:title: Tattoo Design

image:image.image:caption: Sooner or later the theme becomes an obsession that needs to be permanently marked on your life. A close up of part of the flying trilobite inked on my left arm.

image:image.image:caption: Variations of this image, painted on stone, incorporating pencil and digital elements, graced the header of the blog for over half its existence.

The Flying Trilobite Blog - So You Want to Hire a Science Illustrator
image:image.image:caption: Is accuracy important, or are you trying to convey a mood to accompany your writing? Perhaps something instructive, or funny? What type of image will help explain your message? An artist can help you figure that out.

image:image.image:title: The Flying Trilobite Blog - 13 Things I’ve Learned About Being A Science Artist Online
image:image.image:caption: GET OUT THERE AND MAKE SURPRISING NEW CONNECTIONS. (ARTHROPOD MEETING © GLENDON MELLOW)

image:image.image:title: The Flying Trilobite Blog - The Chemistry of Oil Painting
image:image.image:caption: The Mond Crucifixion by Raphael uses two types of oil on different elements to preserve colour and paint film. And the effect still lasts after 500 years, eh?

image:image.image:title: The Flying Trilobite Blog - The Chemistry of Oil Painting
The Flying Trilobite Blog - The Chemistry of Oil Painting
image:image.image:caption: Here you can see the light beams (blue) bouncing multiple times through the oil layers, off oil membranes and off the colourful pigments. This bouncing gives oil paintings their luminous glow.

image:image.image:title: The Flying Trilobite Blog - The Chemistry of Oil Painting
image:image.image:caption: Yellowish, flexible Linseed Oil on the left; Clear, prone-to-cracking Walnut Oil on the right.

image:image.image:title: The Flying Trilobite Blog - The Chemistry of Oil Painting
image:image.image:caption: The old Symbiartic blog banner started out as oil on slate. Tough to photograph, fun to scan. I have no patience and scanned it wet.

image:image.image:title: The Flying Trilobite Blog - Because it's October
The Flying Trilobite Blog - First Frost
image:image.image:caption: A fallen leaf covered in frost.

image:image.image:title: The Flying Trilobite Blog - First Frost
image:image.image:caption: Frost-laden grass in the field at my boys' school.

image:image.image:title: The Flying Trilobite Blog - How To Talk To a Roomful of Artists Who Are Better Than You
image:image.image:caption: The Twitter Essay: keep replying to each of your own sequential tweets (delete your @name), and use 1/m, 2/n until you are finished. Then, when someones sees 32/n retweeted into their feed, they can click on it and see the whole thread.

image:image.image:title: The Flying Trilobite Blog - How To Talk To a Roomful of Artists Who Are Better Than You
image:image.image:caption: I almost didn't include the hashtag info here. It felt like I was putting too much text on the slide.

image:image.image:title: The Flying Trilobite Blog - How To Talk To a Roomful of Artists Who Are Better Than You
image:image.image:caption: Talking about our Symbiartic blog means talking about the #SciArt community.

image:image.image:title: The Flying Trilobite Blog - How To Talk To a Roomful of Artists Who Are Better Than You
image:image.image:caption: One of my first slides, showing a flying trilobite painting. I let descriptive blurbs on the slides tell the jokes for me. © Glendon Mellow.

image:image.image:title: The Flying Trilobite Blog - How To Talk To a Roomful of Artists Who Are Better Than You

image:image.image:title: The Flying Trilobite Blog - How to Destroy Priceless Works of Art
The Flying Trilobite Blog - How to Destroy Priceless Works of Art
image:image.image:caption: Charing Cross Bridge, London. 1901. Claude Monet

image:image.image:title: The Flying Trilobite Blog - How to Destroy Priceless Works of Art
image:image.image:caption: Woman with Eyes Closed, 2002. Lucien Freud.

image:image.image:title: The Flying Trilobite Blog - How to Destroy Priceless Works of Art
image:image.image:caption: Autoporträt, 1889–1891. Meyer de Haan

image:image.image:title: The Flying Trilobite Blog - How to Destroy Priceless Works of Art
image:image.image:caption: Image still from Andy Goldsworthy: A Collaboration with Nature film. Used under Fair Use. Purchase on Amazon, you won’t regret it.

image:image.image:title: The Flying Trilobite Blog - How to Destroy Priceless Works of Art
image:image.image:caption: La Liseuse en Blanc et Jaune, 1919. Henri Matisse.

image:image.image:title: The Flying Trilobite Blog - How to Destroy Priceless Works of Art
image:image.image:caption: Tête d’Arlequin, 1971. Pablo Picasso.

image:image.image:title: The Flying Trilobite Blog - How to Destroy Priceless Works of Art
image:image.image:caption: Pietà, 1498–1499. Michaelangelo. Image from Wikimedia Commons, uploaded by Stanislav Traykov.

image:image.image:title: The Flying Trilobite Blog - How to Destroy Priceless Works of Art
image:image.image:caption: Waterloo Bridge, London, 1901. Claude Monet.

image:image.image:title: The Flying Trilobite Blog - How to Destroy Priceless Works of Art
image:image.image:caption: March 21, 2001, the Buddhas were blown up by the Taliban. Image from Wikimedia, originally from CNN.

image:image.image:title: The Flying Trilobite Blog - How to Destroy Priceless Works of Art
image:image.image:caption: Not a watercolour, but my favourite book of art criticism. D.G. Rossetti from The Langham Series of Monographs, published in 1906. You can see the yellowing acutely: every time I read its pages in the light, I’m hastening its demise.

image:image.image:title: The Flying Trilobite Blog - How to Destroy Priceless Works of Art
image:image.image:caption: Femme devant une fenêtre ouverte, dite la Fiancée, 1888. Paul Gauguin.

image:image.image:title: The Flying Trilobite Blog - It's Inktober!
The Flying Trilobite Blog - It's Inktober!
image:image.image:caption: I've gone deep into my art cabinet and excavated my late grandmother's ink nibs and fountain pens. I think I'll go with a "prehistoric creatures with jack o'lanterns" theme for the month. Find all my sketches here on The Flying Trilobite blog, or on Twitter @FlyingTrilobite. If you want more artists in your Twitter feed, or on Instagram, just check the #inktober hashtag.

image:image.image:title: The Flying Trilobite Blog - Inktober sketch #2
The Flying Trilobite Blog - Inktober sketch #3: exhausted scribbles
image:image.image:caption: A couple of scribbly winged trilobites. Uh-oh, these #inktober sketches are tumbling downhill. Maybe less drawing at 1 in the morning after a long day.

image:image.image:title: The Flying Trilobite Blog - Dilophosaurus Ink at 45
image:image.image:caption: My final Dilophosaurus Cyclist fossil design. © Glendon Mellow, shareable under Creative Commons CC BY-NC-SA.

image:image.image:title: The Flying Trilobite Blog - Dilophosaurus Ink at 45
image:image.image:caption: Work-in-progress in ArtRage. Almost every layer is visible in this mess. Started with rough composition in pale blue, added green on another layer to correct some of the flow, and sketched it in. You can see the early version has a more complicated and delicate gear behind the skull than the final design below - I wanted a bulkier gear so the image would be clearer.

image:image.image:title: The Flying Trilobite Blog - Dilophosaurus Ink at 45
image:image.image:caption: Freshly inked!

image:image.image:title: The Flying Trilobite Blog - Sketching ageless distortions
image:image.image:caption: Sketch of the smaller Stenopterygius quadriscissus. This fossil is 180 million years old, early Jurassic. I curved the tail to fit on the page.

image:image.image:title: The Flying Trilobite Blog - Inktober 2019 — A Field Guide to Flying Trilobites
The Flying Trilobite Blog - Inktober 2019 - week 1
image:image.image:caption: Day 2 - This flying fruit bat-hunting trilobite (Paralejurus artibeus) has large compound eyes for nocturnal vision and wing claws that aid in coral crawling.

image:image.image:title: The Flying Trilobite Blog - Inktober 2019 - week 1
image:image.image:caption: An aggressive, late-summer flying trilobite, Huntonia vespid makes its nest high in the trees, curiously never patrolling lower than 3m above the ground.

image:image.image:title: The Flying Trilobite Blog - Inktober 2019 - week 1
image:image.image:caption: Paleontologists suspect the Brazilian pterosaur Tupandactylus adorned their colourful crests with clay-red trilobites, and refer to these as “Calymene carnivalis”.

image:image.image:title: The Flying Trilobite Blog - Inktober 2019 - week 1
The Flying Trilobite Blog - Inktober 2019 - week 1
image:image.image:caption: Following the clean energy revolution of the 2020s, the “peppered trilobite” saw a shift to a darker variant, that warmed itself on solar panels in the evening.

image:image.image:title: The Flying Trilobite Blog - Inktober 2019 - week 1
image:image.image:caption: Day 3 - The common “flying” trilobite, Olenellus exocoetidae, glides above the waves on diaphanous fins. It is now endangered due to the myth that the the wings have fertility properties.

image:image.image:title: The Flying Trilobite Blog - Inktober 2019 - week 1
image:image.image:caption: Day 4 - Tiny, blind, and highly invasive due to wind-dispersal when mature. Acadagnostus taraxacum, from A Guide to Flying Trilobites.

image:image.image:title: The Flying Trilobite Blog - Inktober 2019 - week 2
image:image.image:caption: The “Maple Bumastus” is a jellybean-shaped tree-dwelling trilobite that chews through the stems of autumn leaves and rides them to the ground. A low, droning “wheeee” sound may be heard.

image:image.image:title: The Flying Trilobite Blog - Inktober 2019 - week 2
image:image.image:caption: ‪“Revivification of this trilobite revealed the function of its mysterious “trident” appendage. ‬ “The remarkably elastic cephalon trident gave this trilobite an easy and unusual escape from predators. ‪”During the war, they were used in a carrier pigeon role with mixed success.” —from A Field Guide to Flying Trilobites ‬

image:image.image:title: The Flying Trilobite Blog - Inktober 2019 - week 2
image:image.image:caption: During the final hours of the Fossil Wars, the Bruce Peninsula Battalion survivors all reported the same apparition. 20 years after the war, “Thysanopeltis pax” became a popular image on AR t-shirts. —from A Field Guide to Flying Trilobites

image:image.image:title: The Flying Trilobite Blog - Inktober 2019 - week 2
image:image.image:caption: ‪“While the exact nature of the ritual that led *homo ergaster* to hurl their Acheulian hand-axes into piles is unknown, the discovery of a unique cache of these finely-crafted tools, laden with trilobite fossils, led to the start of the Fossil Wars.” —from A Field Guide to Flying Trilobites

image:image.image:title: The Flying Trilobite Blog - Inktober 2019 - week 2
image:image.image:caption: “With missions to the enigmatic Comet Phacops so far unsuccessful, astropaleontologists are still unclear if the “comet” represents debris blown into space during the Cambrian, a sculpture by a rogue environmental-artist, or an alarming advance by modern genetic hobbyists.” —from A Field Guide to Flying Trilobites

image:image.image:title: The Flying Trilobite Blog - Inktober 2019 - week 2
image:image.image:caption: “Performing complicated swoops and glides, the patterns the trilobite-kites (Onnia volant) wove in the air were a coded signal to soldiers hidden nearby during the war.” —from A Field Guide to Flying Trilobites

image:image.image:title: The Flying Trilobite Blog - Inktober 2019 - week 2
image:image.image:caption: “The modern proliferation of winged trilobites is as much a product of scientific meme-based humour as it is of genetic and ecological terrorism. Example: the terrifying & beautiful ’Cyphaspis aestiva’.” —from A Field Guide to Flying Trilobites

image:image.image:title: The Flying Trilobite Blog - Inktober 2019 - week 3
image:image.image:caption: “The street artists who defaced the Dudley Cathedral with these trilobite statues along the flying buttresses used matching stone. A decision was made by the historical society to leave them in place.”‬ - from A Field Guide to Flying Trilobites

image:image.image:title: The Flying Trilobite Blog - Inktober 2019 - week 3
image:image.image:caption: “The worldwide helium shortage led to the discovery that these trilobites [Actinopeltis globosus] somehow captured or generated their own.” ‬ ‪-from A Field Guide to Flying Trilobites ‬

image:image.image:title: The Flying Trilobite Blog - Inktober 2019 - week 3
image:image.image:caption: Trilobite Trebuchet “Largely intended to be a symbolic strike, the Ceratobomba trebuchet caused utter devastation to the Closed Circle militants. ‬ ‪The trilobites then crawled back to prepare for another volley.” -from A Field Guide to Flying Trilobites‬

image:image.image:title: The Flying Trilobite Blog - Inktober 2019 - week 3
image:image.image:caption: “Asaphellus velocitas, a key trilobite weaponized for the Fossil War, is considered to have given the decisive edge in the battles of [◼️◼️◼️] and [◼️◼️◼️].” ‬ ‪-from A Field Guide to Flying Trilobites‬

image:image.image:title: The Flying Trilobite Blog - Inktober 2019 - week 3
image:image.image:caption: “Discovery of several spiny trilobites within NIKE OF SAMOTHRACE rocked the fine art world, leading to a fossil “gold rush” among MRI technicians.“ -from A Field Guide to Flying Trilobites

image:image.image:title: The Flying Trilobite Blog - Inktober 2019 - week 3
image:image.image:caption: retpoC icniV aD‬ ‪ot eceip gnissim ehT”‬ ‪ngised s’retsaM eht ekam ‬ ‪a saw lanoitcnuf‬ ‪“.sutarbmif suelcunirT‬ -frome A Field Guide to Flying Trilobites

image:image.image:title: The Flying Trilobite Blog - Inktober 2019 - week 3
image:image.image:caption: “The common spotted red-elytra variant of *Coccinella trilopunctata* proliferated across Europe after the treaty was signed. By the divine, or a splicing artist no one was ever really sure.” — from A Field Guide to Flying Trilobites ‬

image:image.image:title: The Flying Trilobite Blog - Inktober 2019 - week 4
image:image.image:caption: “Asaphus dimorphia is a cliff-dwelling ptero-trilobite. It tends to stay hidden in dry grasses and has a chalky residue.” -from A Field Guide to Flying Trilobites‬

image:image.image:title: The Flying Trilobite Blog - Inktober 2019 - week 4
image:image.image:caption: The popular *Plaice discus*, from A Field Guide to Flying Trilobites. These are often brightly painted by children in class #STEAM projects.

image:image.image:title: The Flying Trilobite Blog - Inktober 2019 - week 4
image:image.image:caption: “With the logical extension of the 1970’s “earthworks” fine art like Spiral Jetty [Robert Smithson], came the pre-contemporary weather-shaping into post genetic kitsch like trilobites.” -from A Field Guide to Flying Trilobites ‬

image:image.image:title: The Flying Trilobite Blog - The Rise of Skywalker - spoiler review and thoughts
The Flying Trilobite Blog - The Rise of Skywalker - spoiler review and thoughts
image:image.image:caption: This whole scene is like an Andrew Wyeth painting. Cannot wait until the Art of The Rise of Skywalker comes out.

image:image.image:title: The Flying Trilobite Blog - The Rise of Skywalker - spoiler review and thoughts

image:image.image:caption: “Custom-crafted by Rose Tico”. The Jungle X-Hopper from The Rise of Skywalker Visual Dictionary by Pablo Hidalgo.
